Regarding the number of connections, there are two things to note:

First, =
HyperNEAT uses all 64 input nodes, even the ones which cannot
legally conta=
in a piece.  The reason why is because we wanted to
compare HyperNEAT's app=
roach to discovering geometric regularities
with NEAT-EI's approach of usin=
g a priori engineered regularities.  If
we disabled the connections that wo=
uld never be activated, we would be
cheating, in a sense, by providing a pr=
iori domain-specific knowledge
to the algorithm.  The only a priori knowled=
ge needed involves the
size of the layers in the substrate and the hidden l=
ayer
configuration.  In this case, the extra connections have no impact on
=
the network, but I left them in ti keep with the spirit of the experiment.
=

Second, all 64*64 + 64*1 (4160) connections in the substrate are not
alway=
s expressed.  If the CPPN outputs a value with a magnitude less
than 0.2, t=
he connection weight is forced to absolute 0, disabling the
connection.  Co=
nnections which are disabled are considered to not
exist, so the 3979 numbe=
r implies that some of the connections were
not expressed in that substrate=
.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:
>
> 
> On =
Apr 11, 2008, at 9:38 PM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> > Jason Gauci and I are =
pleased to share with you new results with
> > HyperNEAT  in our new paper =
to appear in the Twenty-Third AAAI
> > Conference on Artificial Intelligenc=
e (2008), "A Case Study on the
> > Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in=
 Machine Learning."
> 
> 
> Cool, I enjoyed the paper, thanks Jason and Ken=
.
> 
> I have a few questions:
> 
> * Was the 4in/2out CPPN arbitrarily cho=
sen?
> * Why not a 6in/1out (xyz, xyz, out) - which seems more natural to m=
e?
> * Was more than one CPPN configuration tried?  What was the process?
>=
 * Was more than one substrate configuration tried?  ...
> * What was the f=
ull connection pattern through the substrate?  You  
> mention the 129 node=
s (which makes sense), but what are the 3979  
> connections?
> * Did you t=
ry against any opponents other than Xcheckers?
> * Have you experimented wi=
th coevolution?
> 
> Thanks again for the great work.
> --
> Stephen Waits

> steve@...
